material.mattext: Which one of the titration curves shown in the figure better describes the expected titration curve obtained when 50.0 mL of a solution 0.10 M in HCl and 0.20 M in acetic acid is titrated with a 1.0 M NaOH solution?

HCl is neutralized first as a much stronger acid than acetic acid. The length of the pH break at the first equivalence point is relatively short because the solution is still acidic due to acetic acid. At the second equivalent point a larger pH break is expected due to the high alkalinity resulting by the first excess of NaOH That leaves curves B and C as candidates for the right answer. In curve B the ratio of the equivalents of NaOH consumed by the two acids is in accord with the ratio of the equivalents of the two acids in the solution.
In the following gravimetric determinations, indicate the type of analytical error (positive, negative, none) that would result from the following analytical procedures:
Ag+ is precipitated as AgCl with a solution of HCl of higher concentration than that recommended.
Ca2+ is weighed as CaO, after precipitation with ammonium oxalate and ignition of the precipitate, but the ignition temperature was lower than recommended.
Fe3+ is precipitated with NaOH instead of NH3 and the precipitate is ignited and weighed as Fe2O3.
Al3+ is precipitated with an excess of NaOH instead of a NH3 solution and the precipitate is ignited and weighted as Al2O3.
SO42- is precipitated as BaSO4 but the precipitate was subjected to a digestion period longer than recommended.

Aluminum is an amphoteric element and therefore Al(OH)3 is soluble in excess of NaOH. Iron(III) hydroxide adsorbs strongly Na+ that cannot be washed out. Silver forms soluble chloride complexes with concentrated HCl, which escape precipitation. At lower ignition temperatures calcium oxalate does not decompose totally to CaO but in part remains as oxalate and/or carbonate. Increasing the digestion time, the crystal size of BaSO4 is increased making the filtration process easier, therefore no analytical error is expected.
Which one of the indicators shown is appropriate for the following titrations:
Fe2+ with a standard Ce(IV) solution.
Na2CO3 with a standard HCl solution.
H3AsO3 with a standard I2 solution.
Zn2+ with a standard EDTA solution.
H2O2 with a standard KMnO4 solution.

The titration of Fe(II) with Ce(IV) is a redox reaction requiring a redox indicator, such as ferroin. The titration of hydrogen peroxide with permangate doesn't require an indicator, since the permanganate is a coloured titrant. The titration of zinc with EDTA requires a metallochromic indicator such as EBT. Sodium carbonate titration with HCl requires an acid-base (protolytic) indicator such as MO. Starch is a common indicator for titrations involving iodine giving a deep blue/violet colour due to the intercalation complex of starch-iodine.

The dot-plots A to D, shown in the figure, represent the experimental values (e.g. analytical results) obtained by replicate measurements. Associate the accuracy and the precision of the applied method with each dot-plot.
High precision implies more reproducible measurements (less data spread). High accuracy implies a mean value closer to the true mean.

A new instrumental method of analysis is tested under the influence of a variety of experimental parameters. Each set (A, B and C) of experimental parameters yielded a different working curve (measured physical parameter vs. analyte concentration) shown in the figure. By visual inspection of the working curves decide which set:
excludes the use of standard additions as a quantification technique.

The instrumental sensitivity is measured by the slope of the working curve and is The instrumental sensitivity is measured with the slope of the working curve and is constant only in linear working curves. Therefore the highest instrumental sensitivity occurs with 'Set A' and the non-constant instrumental sensitivity with 'Set B' (non-linear working curve). The standard addition technique requires a proportional relation between the measured parameter and the concentration; therefore it cannot be applied with 'Set B'. 'Set C' provides the lowest detection limit (less noisy measurements - less spread of measurements). The most recommended set of experimental conditions is 'Set C', which provides the lowest detection limit and shows an acceptable sensitivity.

The technique of standard known addition is commonly used in instrumental analysis for the quantification of an analyte. Are the following statements true or false?

P : is the measured physical parameter.
[X]: is the unknown concentration of the target analyte X.
A 50-150% increase of P after the addition of the known amount of X is generally recommended .
The sample matrix components alone should not generate signal P.
The sample matrix components should not affect the proportionality constant between P and [X].
The technique can be applied even if instrumental instability (i.e. drift) is encountered.

The standard known addition technique requires proportionality between the measured parameter and the concentration, and absence of systematic error; therefore the background signal (due to matrix components) must be zero. This technique cannot tolerate signal instabilities. The standard addition must cause a significant increase of the measured parameter for statistical reasons (excessive propagation of error). For the same reason a very large signal increase must also be avoided since deviations from linearity at high concentrations of the analyte might appear. Generally, a 50-150% increase is the recommended one. The standard known addition tolerates changes of the proportionality constant due to the matrix components because this constant is finally eliminated and it is not needed for the calculations.

item.title: 07_1C_015 Association of E(t) waveforms to various voltammetries

material.mattext: Associate the potential-time plots (A-D) shown in the figure with the corresponding voltammetric techniques we read below:

Cyclic voltammetry requires a cyclic linear scan of the applied potential (signal A). Stripping voltammetry requires the application of a constant potential for the deposition step and then a linear scan for the stripping step (signal B). Linear scanning voltammetry requires only a linear potential scan (signal C). Differential pulse voltammetry requires the application of short-duration and equidistant potential pulses of equal height on a linearly changing potential (signal D).
The most common electroanalytical determination of the fluoride anion (F-) is based on which one of the following:
the use of an ion-selective electrode with a LaF3 - crystal membrane.
the use of an ion-selective electrode with a membrane based on a multi-crystalline mixture of various insoluble fluoride salts.
the amperometric titration of fluoride with a standard Pb(II) solution.
the voltammetric oxidation of fluoride anion.

The most common, easier and most sensitive method for the determination of fluoride anion in samples makes use of the fluoride ion-selective electrode, which uses as selective membrane, a single crystal of the sparingly soluble LaF3.
What is the mathematical relationship, which describes the dependence of the analytical signal from the concentrations in a potentiometric and an amperometric measurement?
Logarithmic for potentiometric, linear for amperometric.
Linear for potentiometric, logarithmic for amperometric.
Logarithmic for potentiometric, exponential for amperometric.

Potentiometric measurements are based on the use of the Nernst equation, hence the signal is logarithmically related to the concentration of the electroactive analyte. Amperometric signals are diffusion controlled; hence they are linearly related to the concentration of the electroactive analyte.

The real (theoretical) spectrum of an absorbing solution is shown in figure A. The spectrum obtained experimentally is shown in figure B. In order to obtain a spectrum more similar to the real one the following experimental conditions must be applied:
Decrease the exit slit width of the monochromator.
Increase the intensity of the light source.
Increase the voltage applied to the photomultiplier tube.
Use a cell of better quality glass (e.g. quartz).

Decreasing the width of the exit slit of the monochromator (increasing thus the monochromaticity of the light beam) is the only way to increase the resolution of the system and reveal the fine structure of a spectrum. (Beer's Law requires monochromatic light).
Which of the instrumental configurations A-E shown in the figure is more appropriate for measuring:

Configuration A is used for measuring the molecular absorbance. Configuration B is used for fluorescence measurements. Configuration C is used for measuring chemiluminescence. The sample itself is the light source. Configuration D is used for measuring the atomic absorption. Here we need a light source, and a flame to atomise the analyte. Configuration E is used for measuring atomic emission (flame photometry). Here a light source is not needed because the sample is exited and emits light.

The absorption spectra of an aqueous solution of the acid/base indicator "phenol red" (PR), obtained at various pH are shown in figure. The analytical concentration of the indicator is the same in all cases.
Which is the optimal wavelength for the photometric determination of the indicator if:
All PR solutions are strongly acidic (pH<4).
All PR solutions are strongly basic (pH>10).
The pH of all PR solutions have been adjusted at 7.0.
The pH of all PR solutions has not been adjusted.

For strongly acidic solutions the appropriate wavelength is 420 nm (maximum absorbance wavelength of the acidic form of PR). For solutions adjusted to pH 7 or higher the appropriate wavelength is 560 nm (maximum absorbance wavelength of the basic form of PR). If the pH remains unadjusted the appropriate wavelength is 470 nm (isosbestic point of PR).
The quality of the gas chromatogram A (of a mixture of 5 aliphatic hydrocarbons) can be improved to that of B:
By increasing gradually the column temperature during elution.
By increasing the flow rate of the carrier gas.
By increasing the column temperature and the flow rate of the carrier gas.
Chromatogram B can be achieved only by gradual increase of the column temperature (temperature programmed gas chromatography).
In gas chromatography, the retention index (Kovats' index) of a normal (straight-chain) alkane n−CmH2m+2 depends:
On the number of carbon atoms (m) of its molecule.
On the nature of the static phase of the chromatographic column.
On the temperature and the flow rate of the mobile phase.
On all instrumental parameters (static phase, column temperature, flow rate of the mobile phase).
By definition, Kovats' index of any normal alkane with m carbons is equal to 100 m, therefore for n−alkanes it only depends on the number m.

Paper chromatography using as mobile phase n-butanol saturated with an aqueous 3 M HCl solution can effectively separate a mixture of Cu2+, Pb2+, Bi3+, Cd2++ and Hg2+. Dithizone or rhodizonic acid can be used for the development of the chromatogram.

The following RF values were obtained with a standard solution containing the following metal cations:

Cu2+: 0.20;  Pb2+: 0.27;  Bi3+: 0.59;  Cd2+: 0.77;  Hg2+: 0.81
Identify the metal ions contained in an unknown sample, which give bands A and B in the paper chromatogram shown in the figure.
For band A the retardation retention factor (RF) is about 5.6/20 = 0.28, corresponding to Pb(II), whereas for band B RF is about 15.6/20 = 0.78 corresponding to Cd(II).
The (metal) ion A is to be titrated with EDTA in the presence of (metal) ion B. What reagent must be added in excess to eliminate co-titration of B and avoid interference?

Fluoride forms stable complexes with Fe(III), allowing the titration of Zn(II) only. Cyanide forms stable complexes with Zn(II), allowing the titration of Mg(II) only. At pH 12 only Mg(II) is precipitated as hydroxide and is removed from the solution, allowing the titration of Ca(II) only. Bi(III) forms much more stable complexes with EDTA compared to Mg(II), therefore only Bi(III) is titrated with EDTA at pH 3.

The mean iron content in a sample of a tap water was determined by a spectrophotometric method and was found 1.25 mg/L. The standard deviation of this determination is known to be 0.10 mg/L. Calculate the percent probability (P%) that a single measurement will give a result within the 1.20-1.30 mg/L range.

The 1.20-1.30 mg/L range corresponds to the mean value ±0.5x(standard deviation) (Z = 0.5). The table indicates that the area (integral) under the Gaussian curve corresponding to Z = 0.5 is 0.3829; therefore the expected probability will be about 38.3%.

In the following figure 4 data sets (A-D) are shown. If the equation y = Bx + A is to be used to fit the data, associate (by visual inspection) the following values of the correlation coefficients (r) to each set.

The correlation coefficient (r) is a measure of the strength of the mutual dependence between y and x. For an absolutely linear dependence the value of r must be 1 or -1 for positive and negative slope, respectively. Absolute values of r<<1 or r=0 indicate a weak (poor) or chaotic dependence, respectively.

item.title: 19_2C_011 Effect of EDTA on Tl(I)-Pb(II) polarogram

material.mattext:
The polarographic waves of thallium(I) and lead(II) in a non-complexing carrier electrolyte solution (e.g. KNO3) almost overlap at E1/2 = −0.4 (vs. SCE).
It is known that lead(II) but not thallium(I) forms a very stable complex with EDTA. In which of the following media are one (indicate which) or both of these metals present?
In a KNO3 medium a single wave is observed at −0.4 V.
In a KNO3-EDTA medium two waves are observed at −0.4 V and −1.3 V.
In a KNO3-EDTA medium a single wave is observed at −0.4 V.
In a KNO3-EDTA medium a single wave is observed at −1.3 V.

In the absence of EDTA the polarographic waves of Pb(II) and Tl(I) practically coincide, therefore a single wave at −0.4 V may be attributed to Tl(I) or Pb(II) or both, so the analytical result is uncertain. EDTA shifts the polarographic wave of Pb(II) to more negative values, therefore a single wave in the presence of EDTA at −0.4 V indicates only Tl(I), whereas a single wave at −1.3 V indicates only Pb(II). In the presence of EDTA two waves (at −0.4 and −1.3 V) indicate the presence of both metals.

item.title: 20_2C_012 Amperom. titrations of Pb-SO4, Pb-CrO4, Cu-EDTA

material.mattext: Associate the amperometric titration graphs (A-D) shown in the figure with the following titration experiments (all potentials are measured vs. saturated calomel electrode):
SO42-, titrated with Pb(NO3)2, is monitored at −1.0 V, where Pb2+ is reduced in a 2e- step.
A mixture of Ba2+ and Pb2+ is titrated with K2CrO4, and monitored at −1.0 V, where Pb2+ is reduced in a 2e- step and CrO42- in a 3e- step.
Cu2+, titrated with complexing titrant L, is monitored at −1.5 V, where Cu2+ is reduced in a 2e- step and L in a 1e- step.
Cu2+, titrated with EDTA, is monitored at −0.2 V, where only Cu2+ is reduced, in a 2e- step.

- Curve A indicates the titration of Cu2+ with EDTA: The current decreases to zero and remains zero after the equivalent point (EP) because the Cu(II)-EDTA complex is not electroactive at −0.2 V.

- Curve B indicates the titration of Ba2+ and Pb2+ at −1.0 V with CrO42-: Initially the current decreases up to the 1st EP due only to the decrease of Pb2+, which is precipitated as PbCrO4. CrO42- is consumed by reacting with the Ba2+ (forming the precipitate BaCrO4) up to the 2nd EP and the current remains constant because Ba2+ is not electroactive. After the completion of Ba2+ precipitation the current increases again due to the increasing concentration of CrO42-, which is electroactive (it is reduced to Cr3+). The slopes of the first and the third steps are consistent with the number (2 and 3) of participating electrons.

- Curve C indicates the titration of Pb2+ with SO42-: Sulfate is a non-electroactive ion and gives zero current after the EP the current increases due to the gradual increase of the electroactive Pb2+ concentration.

- Curve D indicates the titration of Cu2+ with the electroactive ligand L: Cu2+ is complexed and the current decreases up to the EP. After this point the ligand L is in excess and is reduced, its current increases as its concentration is increased.

A photometric titration is described by the reaction:

AN (analyte) + TI (titrant) → PR (product)
Associate the photometric titration curves shown in the figure, with the combinations of absorbing properties of AN, TI and PR given bellow (dilution effects are not considered):
AN and TI absorb, PR does not absorb.
TI and PR absorb, AN does not absorb.

Curve A is obtained when only TI absorbs.
Curve B is obtained when AN and TI absorb and PR does not.
Curve C is obtained when TI and PR absorb and AN does not.
Curve D is obtained when only AN absorbs.
Curve E is obtained when only PR absorbs.
For each pair (A-E) of chemical species given below, indicate which species (left / right) is expected to exhibit more intense fluorescence.

Pair A: right (aromatic, more rigid molecular structure).
Pair B: left (carbonyl and carboxyl groups generally decrease the fluorescence).
Pair C: left (free aniline has more resonance forms stabilizing the first excited state and enhancing fluorescence).
Pair D: right (more rigid molecular structure, planar).
Pair E: right (more rigid molecular structure, planar).

The gas chromatogram A, obtained with a mixture of methanol, ethanol and n-propanol using a capillary glass column, gave 'highly-tailed' peaks.
What action might be the most appropriate in order to improve the quality of the chromatogram to a B type chromatogram?
Use a capillary column with silanized walls.
Use a longer glass capillary column.
Use a different type of detector.

Tailing is due to the strong adsorption of the polar alkanols on the free −OH groups, on the surface of the glass column. By silanization these groups are substituted by non-polar long alkyl groups and tailing is alleviated.

How many consecutive extractions of a 500 mL aqueous iodine (I2) solution 0.0010 M in I2 with 25 mL of CCl4 (each time) is needed to remove at least 99% of I2 from the aqueous to the organic phase? The distribution ratio (D) of I2 in the CCl4/H2O system is 90.
It is Cn/C0 = [ Vw / (D x Vo + Vw)]n, hence 1.0 / 100 = [500 / (90x25 + 500)]n resulting in n = 2.70, therefore the minimum number of extractions required is 3.

item.title: 25_2F_006 Mixture of beta-emmiting isotopes A and B

material.mattext:
Beta-emitting isotopes A and B have half-lives of 10 and 20 hours, respectively. The decay products of both isotopes are not radioactive.
In a mixture of A and B prepared with quantities of equal radioactivity, calculate which one of the following percentages represents the remaining radioactivity of this mixture after 40 hours?

For isotope A, 40 hours correspond to 4 half-lives therefore 1/(2^4) = 1/16 of the initial activity remains. For isotope B, 40 hours correspond to 2 half-lives therefore 1/(2^2) = 1/4 of the initial activity remains. Starting with quantities of A and B of equal radioactivity we have: Initial radioactivity: 1+1 = 2, final (after 40 hours) radioactivity: (1/16) + (1/4) = 0.3125 radioactivity units. Hence the final radioactivity is equal to (0.3125/2) x 100 = 15.6% of the initial value.

Successive analytical results for standard samples containing 4.0, 8.0 and 12.0 ppm Fe are shown in the following figure. By visual inspection of these plots, estimate which one of the following values is closest to the limit of detection (LOD) for the particular method used.
The scattering of the data points indicates a standard deviation of about 1 ppm. Since the LOD is generally defined as equal to about 3 times the standard deviation, the estimated LOD is 3 ppm.

item.title: 27_3C_001 Effect of scanning rate on voltammograms

material.mattext: The figure below shows three voltammographic scans obtained with aqueous samples containing a certain electroactive compound. Which one of the following parameters was altered and resulted in the change of the shape of the obtained voltammograms from 1 to 3?
The scanning rate of the potential was increased.
The active surface of the working electrode was increased.
The pH of the tested solutions was increased.
The concentration of the electroactive compound was increased.

The scanning rate of the potential was increased. At very low scanning rates enough time is given to electroactive species to move from the bulk of the solution to the electrode area to replenish the depleted diffusion layer, that may result in an almost sustainable current (curve 1). Upon increasing the scanning rate, the same number of electroactive species reacts in a shorter time period, therefore the current increases much faster (curves 2 and 3) and no time is given for replenishing the depleted diffusion layer, resulting into a peak-shaped voltammetric signal.

An electrically heated tungsten wire is a common source of continuous radiation. Its radiation spectrum approximates that of the ideal blackbody and it is shown in the figure as curve X. Upon increasing its temperature (e.g. by increasing the electric current passing through it), which one of the following changes of its emission spectrum takes place?
The relative radiation energy increases. The wavelength of the peak maximum does not change, being exclusively dependent on the wire material (curve 3).
The relative radiation energy increases. The wavelength of the peak maximum is shifted toward smaller wavelengths (curve 2).
The peak relative energy remains almost the same but the peak is getting wider spreading toward both directions, so that an almost perfect white light spectrum is obtained (curve 1).
The relative radiation energy increases. The wavelength of the peak maximum is shifted towards higher wavelengths (curve 4), a phenomenon known as 'red shift'.

Curve 2 is the correct one. The energy increases and the peak of the radiation spectrum is shifted to shorter wavelengths (Wien's law: wavelength of maximum intensity x temperature = λmax x T = constant).
Characterize the following pairs of features or terms as either related exclusively to Gas Chromatography (GC), to High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC), or to both (GC+HPLC):
Polarity of mobile phase, post-column reactor.

<HR>Packed columns and silanization are used in both GC and HPLC. The polarity of the mobile phase and post-column reactors are associated only with HPLC. Temperature programming and Kovats' index are associated only with GC. Size exclusion and isocratic elution are associated only with HPLC. Derivatization of the analyte and the general concept of the theoretical plate are associated with both GC and HPLC.

Associate the ionic fragments listed below with the isotopic lines (A-E) shown in the figure. The natural isotopic abundances of the elements involved are:

35Cl: 75.8%;  37Cl: 24.2%;  79Br: 50.7%;  81Br: 49.3%

The shown spectra are of 2 or 3 lines. A 2-lines spectrum corresponds to a monatomic ion. Its identity can be found considering the relative abundance of the 2 isotopes of given atom. A 3-lines spectrum corresponds to a diatomic ion. Its identity can be found considering the probability of any line. Therefore:
- Spectrum A corresponds to Cl2+: 3 lines are expected [35+35 = 70, 35+37 = 72, 37+37 = 74], the last one is the smallest of all last lines (of all 3-lines spectra) due to the lower percentage of 37Cl (line-height proportional to 0.2422 = 0.059).
- Spectrum B corresponds to ClBr+: 3 lines are expected [35+79 = 114, 37+79 = 35+81 = 116, 37+81 = 118], the last one has a medium size compared to the last lines of all 3-lines spectra (line-height proportional to 0.242x0.493 = 0.119).
- Spectrum C corresponds to Cl+: 2 lines are expected [35, 37], their ratio corresponds to the ratio of the isotopic abundances of 35Cl and 37Cl.
- Spectrum D corresponds to Br2+: 3 lines are expected [79+79 = 158, 79+81 = 160, 81+81 = 162], the last one is the highest of all last lines of all 3-lines spectra due to the relatively high percentage of 81Br (line height proportional to 0.4932 = 0.243).
- Spectrum E corresponds to Br+: 2 lines are expected [79, 81], their ratio corresponds to the ratio of the isotopic abundances of 79Br and 81Br.
